intro: Psammotropha mucronata var. foliosa, commonly known as the desert flax, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its fern-like foliage and small, yellowish flowers. The plant has a fibrous root system that helps it survive in sandy and rocky soils. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered in fine hairs, which reduce water loss. The plant produces small, dry fruits that contain seeds, aiding in its propagation in harsh environments.
